title: TraceChain is extremely slow and affects to block synchronization
body:
## Content 
I'm using traceChain to get all internal transaction.
I found traceChain tracer from this issue: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/3128


When traceChain is executed with a length of 50 or less, traceChain return the result in 2~3 minutes. However, when the length is 100 or larger, traceChain returns error with 1 hour or larger(!).

In this situation, geth outputs many warnings like: `Tracer accessed out of bound memory`.

After traceChain is executed, geth start to fail to synchronize gradually with the following error: `Synchronisation failed, retrying  err="block download canceled (requested)"`and `Synchronisation failed, dropping peer    peer=xxx err=timeout`.

Finally, geth loses all peers and stop to synchronize.


Is there any way to retrieve internal transactions efficiently?
I think the load of traceChain affects to block synchronization.

## System information
Geth version: `1.8.15`
OS & Version: Linux
Pod specs(running on GKE) :    CPU: 64 vCPU,   MEM: 64 GB

## Expected behaviour
TraceChain finishes with success and not affect to block synchronization.

## Actual behaviour
TraceChain finishes with a timeout and stops block synchronization.

## Steps to reproduce the behaviour
1 Run geth with the following configuration:
```
--gcmode=archive
--maxpeers=50
--rpc
--rpcaddr=0.0.0.0
--rpcapi=web3,eth,debug
--rpcvhosts=*
--ws
--wsaddr=0.0.0.0
--wsapi=web3,eth,debug
--wsorigins=*
```
2. Wait until geth is synced (not using fastsync is recommended)
3. Execute traceChain by debug_subscribe method with websocket. like:
method: debug_subscribe
params: ["traceChain", "6475620", "6475745", { tracer: "callTracer", timeout: "10m"}] // method, from, to, tracer_configuration

I dunno if I have the same issue, but what, as a user, am I supposed to do when I see "Tracer accessed out of bound memory"? What is that message actually telling me? Does the application need more RAM? Or is it always a bug? Thanks.

> What is that message actually telling me? Does the application need more RAM? Or is it always a bug? 

That is most definitely always a bug

EDIT: it's in fact when the javascript tracer tries to access out of bounds memory. I've made a PR which should make these messages go away.

So there are two things in this PR:

- The slowness: transaction tracing needs to reexecute all those past blocks, and not only that, but crunch through and interpret all the opcodes via javascript. That is a very heavy toll on the node. Also since we do it on all available cores, it does hit block processing I guess. Perhaps an option to specify the allowed concurrency could be useful.
- The `Tracer accessed out of bound memory` message is not an error and you don't need more memory. It just states that the tracer wanted to read EVM memory that's not allocated. That's generally a faulty contract doing something funky. There are quite a few on the chain.
